content:
This is a fun clash for shortest, except that you explicitly state that the answer should be rounded to 1 dp, but then all of the tests and validators give answers that need no rounding as since you have integer inputs there is no way to get more than 1 dp in your answer (sum of integer products divided by 2 will always be 1 dp at worst).

For shortest mode it can be the difference between winning and losing to include ".round(1)", so it would be nicer if the statement said something like "all answers should be shown as floats with 1 decimal place". But this is just nitpicking really, nice clash. :)
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.
where is specified the output must be expressed with one decimal digit, even when not needed?
I think that this problem is a little too difficult for a reverse CoC. Maybe you should let it just for fastest and shortest.
Would be extremely hard for Reverse
There is no requirement of convexity here
It’s a CoC and in the last cases, the quadrilateral is not convex.

I agree.  If you use floating point arithmetic most languages probably put a .0 in the string representation but I wouldn't say that all languages do.  Also the math on these test cases and validations works out to .0 or .5 and nothing longer that but I think that it should be specified for clarity and let people know they should be handling these as floating point arithmetic (or decimal).
Is there a way that I can ensure both 20 and 20.0 are acceptable answers?
I don't believe so.   It is a literal string comparison of the output of the program and the test case/validator string.
